locations.name: RAI
locations.description:
RAI – Radiotelevisione italiana S.p.A., known until 1954 as Radio Audizioni Italiane is the national public broadcasting company of Italy, owned by the Ministry of Economy and Finance. RAI operates many terrestrial and subscription television channels and radio stations. It is the biggest television broadcaster in Italy and competes with Mediaset, and other minor television and radio networks. RAI has a relatively high television audience share of 33.8%. 
RAI broadcasts are also received in neighbouring countries, including Albania, Bosnia, Croatia, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, San Marino, Slovenia, Vatican City, Switzerland, and Tunisia, and elsewhere on pay television. Sometimes Rai 1 was received even further in Europe via Sporadic E until the digital switch off in July 2012. 
Half of the RAI's revenues come from broadcast receiving licence fees, the rest from the sale of advertising time. In 1950, the RAI became one of the 23 founding broadcasting organizations of the European Broadcasting Union.

locations.name: Piazza Duomo
locations.description:
Trento’s Piazza Duomo is the buzzing heart of this city, the capital of the Trentino region. Duomo in Italian means Cathedral, and Trento’s Cathedral San Vigilio does indeed dominate the square, but there are lots of things that are equally important and interesting to see in this square.
The square from the middle-ages onwards became home to the civic and religious administration of the city, although before 1000 a.d it was an area beyond the city’s walls. The outward expansion of the city centred on this area, around a church dedicated to the city’s patron St. Vigilius, and with the construction of the Palazzo Pretorio and the Duomo it cemented its position as the main square of the city.

locations.name: Palazzo della Provincia
locations.description:
Located inside the Palace of the Autonomous Province of Trento overlooking Piazza Dante, Sala Depero was in the past a sumptuous dining room of the Imperial Hotel Trento, then it became the seat of art exhibitions from the late twenties.It owes its name to Fortunato Depero, an artist from Rovereto (painter, sculptor and advertising) who, between 1953 and 1956, turned it into a work of art performing there his land in a colourful harmony combining futurism, cubism and abstract art . The decor was inspired by the movements of the Mitteleuropa aesthetics, born in the mid-nineteenth century, which had their maximum and most mature expression in the first two decades of the twentieth century, particularly the Secession of Vienna. All revisited and mitigated with an Italian taste that reduces its grandeur. The manufacture was entrusted to local artisans. From 1948 to 1960, it hosted the sessions of the provincial Council and the regional one.
The entrance from Piazza Dante has steps, while from Via Vannetti is barrier-free (ramp of 303cm with a difference in height of 6.6% and a bell height of 119cm). On the floor of the porter's lodge, there are Sala Depero and the toilets with grab bars on both sides (door width: 90cm, internal dimensions 180x200cm, toilet 50cm high). The Braille push-button lift (door width 90cm, dimensions 137x150) allows to reach the various floors of the building. Five parking areas reserved for people with disabilities in via Gazzoletti.

locations.name: Social Theater
locations.description:
The charm of this place is not only linked to the beauty of a 'real' theater, but in large part to the suggestions that it manages to evoke thanks to its history that begins on May 29, 1819 with the staging of 'La Cenerentola' by Gioachino Rossini. The theater was called Teatro Mazzurana, named after Felice Mazzurana, promoter of the construction and first owner. In 1835 the entrepreneur-coffee maker sold the property and the Theater changed its name to Teatro Sociale, run by the Theater Company. In nineteenth-century Trento, the Teatro Sociale was the driving force of an intense cultural activity, hosting events that went from opera to prose, from dance to classical music, but was also used for political meetings, balls, magic shows. 
Places reserved for disabled people in the first rows. The elevator (door width: 100cm, dimensions 150x180 cm) allows you to reach the Volkenstein hall and Palazzo Festi; the stage can be reached by a step from the back of the building. On the ground floor there are the toilets equipped with grab bars on both sides (door width 93 cm, internal dimensions 280x200 cm, height 50 cm). Parking reserved for people with disabilities located at 50 meters from the theater along Via Manci.

locations.name: Buonconsiglio Castle
locations.description:
The Buonconsiglio Castle is the largest and most important monumental complex of the Trentino Alto Adige region. It was the residence of the prince-bishops of Trento from the 13th century to the end of the 18th century, and is composed of a series of buildings of different eras, enclosed by walls and positioned slightly higher than the city. Castelvecchio is the oldest nucleus, dominated by an imposing cylindrical tower; the Magno Palazzo is the 16th century expansion in the Italian Renaissance-style as commissioned by the Prince-Bishop and Cardinal Bernardo Cles (1485-1539); the Baroque-style Giunta Albertiana dates from the end of the 17th century.
The Marangonerie Room hosted the Historical Museum in Trento from 1985 until 2003. Currently, in addition to the bookshop, in the hall there is a first information point about the four sites of the museum. The size of the room allows it to be used for conferences, meetings, as well as, naturally, to be an exhibition space for temporary exhibitions. Parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities can be found in Piazza della Mostra.

locations.name: Palazzo Geremia
locations.description:
This palace is one of the most important secular monuments in the city. Its architectonic structure is double-faced: clearly Renaissance on the outside looking onto Via Belenzani and late Gothic on the inside. Thus, it is an expression of the change from Gothic to Renaissance and is influenced by both the Lombard and the Veneto art. 
Built between the end of the 15th century and the first years of the 16th by order of Giovanni Antonio Pona, known as Geremia, son of Geremia Pona, a citizen of Trento belonging to a family from Verona, it seems that Pona used free workmen who were active in Trento at that time.

locations.name: Cinema Modena
locations.description:
The Cinema Theater Gustavo Modena of Trento - named after the great nineteenth-century actor originally from Mori - was founded in 1911 thanks to the entrepreneurial initiative of Giuseppe Lazzeri who created a popular open-air theater, building a stage overlooking a large square where, under a large tarpaulin to shelter from the frequent summer rains, spectators sat on wooden benches. The project was drafted by a Viennese architect who conceived a dome-shaped roof supported by arches made of fine wooden trellis (1912). The original structure, although modified several times, was maintained until 1997, when, in just 11 months, the current three screens structure was built, giving rise to the first real multiplex cinema in Trentino. 
A ramp of 20m with a gradient of 19% leads to the entrance of the cinema, where a door with manual opening towards the outside is placed (246cm wide, 105cm high, force required to open it: 2kg). Three tiered screening rooms allow wheelchair users to stop in the last row. There are toilets with grab bars on both sides of the toilet (90cm door, internal space 183x183cm, height 46cm). In Via San Francesco d'Assisi there is a car park reserved for people with disabilities.

locations.name: UNITN - Department of Economics and Management
locations.displayString: UNITN - Department of Economics and Management - Conference Hall
locations.description:
The Department is the outgrowth of the Faculty of Economics and Commerce, which was founded in Trento in 1973. As a new academic institution, it brought together the two historical branches of Economics (DECO) and Informatics and Business Studies (DISA). The Department (DEM) is actively involved in numerous fields of economic and management research and its members have intrinsically diverse interests – from the theoretical to the empirical, quantitative to experimental, and case study analysis to computer simulations. DEM hosts a multidisciplinary research environment where academics apply a wide array of methodologies. 
Possibility to enter the Department of Economics and Management from via Rosmini with platform (105x143 cm, door 80 cm); regularly paved outdoor garden. Presence of ramps with variable slope from a minimum of 7.5% to a maximum of 10%, for lengths from 74 cm to 1000 cm. On the ground floor near the entrance: reception (counter 115 cm high) and ATM (125 cm high). The conference room on the ground floor is accessible, the stage can be reached with a 135 cm long slide and a 25.3% slope. Sala Soppalco reachable with stairlift (85x80 capacity 130 kg). All floors are accessible and all classrooms are accessible; in some rooms there are steps, with the possibility of stopping in the first row or in the upper part of the stalls. In the equipped toilets grab bars are placed on both sides (50 cm high). The parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities can be found in via Inama, other 3 stalls in the underground car park.

locations.name: Bruno Kessler Foundation
locations.description:
Top Research Institute in Italy, ranked at the 1st place for scientific excellence within 3 different subject areas (ICT, History and Sociology) and for the economic and social impact according to the quality of research ANVUR evaluation for the period 2010-2014.
Fondazione Bruno Kessler is a research non-profit public interest entity.
Being the result of a history that is more than half a century old, through 2 scientific hubs, 7 research centres, 410 researchers, 2 specialized libraries, 7 laboratories, FBK aims to results of excellence in science and technology with particular emphasis on interdisciplinary approaches and to the applicative dimension.
We achieve this thanks to our constant attention to collaborations and exchange activities with research organizations, both institutional and corporate, national and international, which extend our innovation capability and involve the community and the local economy in the circulation of knowledge and technologies.

locations.name: Philharmonic Hall
locations.description:
Founded in 1795 the Trento Philharmonic Society carried out its activity in various buildings of the city until 1905. The building where it is currently located was completed in a year, and inaugurated with a concert directed by Mo Vincenzo Gianferrari on May 30, 1905. The structure of the building includes a basement, a mezzanine floor with eight rooms and a small apartment for the concierge , the Concert Hall with two service rooms on the first floor, three rooms with five loggias towards the upper part of the Hall on the third floor. Except for very few modifications, the building still looks like when it was built in 1905.
The reserved parking spaces are in via Maffei. Presence of two other stalls along the way at about 100 meters. Entry without barriers for people with disabilities from Vicolo Pievano. The room is open according to the scheduled shows. Access to the Concert Hall through a 140 cm wide manual door. Access to the stage with 3 steps 22.5 cm high. The equipped toilets have grab bars on both sides.

locations.name: Municipal Library
locations.description:
In the historic center, between via Torre Vanga and via Pozzo, with entrance on via Roma, the municipal library of Trento is located in the building of the former Jesuit College. The founding act of the municipal library of Trento, officially open to the public on January 1, 1856 - a period in which Trento and Trentino were part of the Land of Tyrol with the capital Innsbruck - can be identified in the will of the bishop Giovanni Benedetto Gentilotti who donated ten thousand volumes of his large library, collected during a long activity as a scholar, librarian and collector between Salzburg, Vienna and Rome. The municipal library of Trento has therefore arisen as an institution dedicated to the memory and documentation of the (Italian) culture of the territory. 
The entrance door of the municipal library is 216 cm wide, 138cm high and requires a force of 4kg to open. Toilet facilities, accessible via a 8.24m long ramp with a gradient of 6.5%, have grab bars on both sides (89cm door, 175x169cm interior room mosaic, 46cm height toilet). Parking reserved for people with disabilities are in via Roma.

locations.name: Franco Demarchi Foundation
locations.description: Born as evolution and development of the Regional Institute of Studies and Social Research; The Demarchi Foundation aims to promote and carry out training and research in the social, educational and cultural fields for the benefit of local communities and their development. It also deals with training activities, continuous training and education and lifelong learning.

locations.name: Palazzo Bassetti
locations.description:
Palazzo Bassetti is now home to Intesa Sanpaolo, formerly the headquarters of the Banca di Trento and Bolzano since 1960. Once home to the Barons Bassetti, it was renovated by Eng. Saverio Tamanini (1833-1887), 'cultured and gentle spirit, artist of exquisite taste', one of the most famous professionals involved in the development of the city in the second half of the 19th century.  The BTB inaugurates the new salon in 1961 and restructures the entire building in 2000 (design by the architect Sergio Giovanazzi). 
The conference room, located on the fourth floor, can be reached by elevator (75cm wide door, 289x279cm size). The speakers area has an 18 cm high step. The toilets equipped with grab bars on the side (47 cm high) are located on the ground floor. Other equipped toilets are present near the conference room (220x173 cm, door 80 cm, toilet 46 cm high with grab bars on both sides). In via Manci, parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities.

locations.name: Auditorium Santa Chiara
locations.description: The Auditorium Santa Chara is the largest theater in the city of Trento and its peculiarity is that from all seats there is good visibility. Recently renovated (in the summer of 2006), the Auditorium presents itself with an elegant and modern look. The excellent acoustics is perfect for symphonic music, while the sound-absorbing devices make it a perfect location for light music events and author's theater. The space is equipped with a cafeteria, recently renovated in a new modern and welcoming layout, ideal place for meetings with actors / authors and the public.

locations.name: Department of Humanities and Philosophy
locations.description: The Department of Humanities and Philosophy is based in via Tommaso Gar n. 14. It is located in the historic center, a few hundred meters from Piazza Duomo and can be reached in about 5 minutes on foot from the train and bus station.

locations.name: Department of Sociology
locations.description: The inner courtyard of the department is paved in pebbles with porphyry lanes; inside the structure, in addition to the 127 cm entrance ramp with a gradient of 8.4%, there are other ramps from a minimum of 5.4% to a maximum of 13.9%, for lengths from 30 cm to 695 cm. The concierge, some offices and part of the laboratories can be reached by lift and by stair lift (75x80 capacity 230 kg). Access to the Kessler classroom with a 130 cm wide door, accessible throughout its perimeter with the exception of the final steps. Places reserved for people with disabilities in the first rows. The speakers area of the hall can be reached by an elevating platform (90x120) preceded by a 40 cm long ramp with a gradient of 20.2%. The toilets, equipped with grab bars on the opposite side (53 cm high), are on the first and second floor. Parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities can be found in via Verdi and via Maffei.

locations.name: OECD Offices
locations.displayString: Convent of San Marco - OECD Offices
locations.description:
The convent of S. Marco, now home to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, originates from the permission to establish an Augustinian settlement in the city in a place that was then at the edge of the urban center and near the Castle, granted in 1271 to the small community of Emeritan friars that had already been installed in Barbaniga di Civezzano during the first decades of the 13th century. As a result of the third French invasion, in 1809, Trento was annexed to the Italic Kingdom and the Augustinians were ordered to evacuate the Convent of San Marco, which became the headquarters of the Finance and State Property Office. 
Floor in cobblestone. The entrance door of the former convent has a 145 cm wide automatic opening. The rooms and offices can be reached via steps; the gardens, with a floor in cobblestones and grass, are free of barriers. Two parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities in via San Marco.

locations.name: School of Law - Room B
locations.description: The B Room is located in the basement of the Faculty and has 175 seats. Equipped for simultaneous translation, control room, audio-video systems, CCTV camera and videoconference - telephone connections, internet. In the Faculty there are elevators located in several points that allow you to reach all floors. Presence of internal and external ramps with gradient from 6.3% to 7.7% and length from a minimum of 355 cm to a maximum of 395 cm. The toilets on the ground floor are equipped with grab bars on both sides (49 cm high). The parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities are in via Verdi and via Rosmini.

locations.name: School of Law - Great Hall
locations.description:
The Conference Hall of the Faculty of Law was inaugurated in October 2006 in the new wing designed along Via Rosmini by architect Mario Botta. With its 370 seats overall is the ideal venue for conferences and events of the faculty but also of the university. Modern and versatile, it can be divided into two separate classrooms through a sliding wall. It is equipped with a cabin for simultaneous translation, a control room and complete with audio video systems, CCTV cameras and videoconferencing facilities, telephone connections and the Internet. The new headquarters also features a large hall where the faculty reception is located, a cloakroom and a space for organizing coffee breaks and buffet lunches. 
The Great Hall has steps 12.5 cm high and 97 cm deep; the speakers area is not accessible. There are elevators located in several points of the Faculty that allow you to reach all floors. Presence of internal and external ramps with slope from 6.3% to 7.7% and length from a minimum of 355 cm to a maximum of 395 cm. The toilets on the ground floor are equipped with grab bars on both sides (49 cm high). On all floors there are dedicated bathrooms. Parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities are in via Verdi and via Rosmini.

locations.name: MUSE
locations.description:
The Autonomous Province of Trento asked starchitect Renzo Piano to create in a disused industrial area of approximately 19,000 sqm not just a museum, but a place to reflect on the relationship between nature and man. That is how the MUSE was born - so successful that it was the only museum in Italy to be awarded an honourable mention at the European Museum of the Year Awards 2015.
From the mountains to the challenges of sustainability, from the first men on Earth to the DNA’s secrets. With “special effects” to experience virtually the same emotions of a climb on the Dolomites walls or a downhill skiing descent.A very real experience, however, is touching with your own hand fossils and minerals, using the microscope and going into the large greenhouse with living plants from the Tanzania forest.
And more, the dinosaurs of the Alpine region, their footprints, the first painted stones and the weapons of prehistoric hunters in the ice age. In a science gym you can learn the principles of physics and mechanics with the help of interactive installations.

locations.name: Palazzo Calepini
locations.description:
In the heart of the historic center, behind the Cathedral of Trento, on the corner between Via Calepina and Via Garibaldi, Palazzo Calepini was for decades the headquarters of the Istituto di Credito Fondiario of Trentino Alto Adige. Now owned by the Cassa di Risparmio Foundation of Trento and Rovereto, the Palazzo is used as its registered and administrative office. A recent renovation has canceled the pre-existing 'banking' structure of the ground floor, leaving space for a large and modern conference room, with 150 seats and equipped with cutting-edge technology that makes it suitable for hosting conferences,  symposia, round tables, etc. 
The entrance door is always open and followed by a counter-door with a 120cm wide automatic opening (on request, access without barriers from Via Dordi, 8). The toilets have a grab bar on the side (43 cm high). Reserved parking for people with disabilities is located in Via Calepina.

locations.name: Palazzo della Regione
locations.description:
The lot where the Palazzo della Regione stands is located near the Trento railway station and includes the Regional Council offices, the local government offices and the Council Chamber. The program’s different required functions are solved with three independent volumes. The two rectangular and one trapezoidal spaces are interconnected in an 'L' shaped plan.
The Trento Palazzo della Regione construction is a post-World War II project. Adalberto Libera’s architectural language seems completely different from the pure and rationalist one that had characterized its pre-war cycle. During the war, the architect had spent a period of voluntary confinement in his birthplace, Villa Lagarina, in Trentino. Back in Rome, he chose to start over, based on his profound theoretical reflections at Villa Lagarina. After the post-war enthusiasm with German-style idealism, Libera’s architecture preferred 'correctness' to great rationalist ideals.

sessions.title: Tutta la città ne parla
sessions.description:
hosted by Pietro Del Soldà 
produced by Cristiana Castellotti with Rosa Polacco

This daily public radio show will broadcast live from the city main’s square during the Festival, discussing the day’s main topics with key speakers, authors and other guests.

sessions.title: Inauguration
sessions.description:
speakers:
Alessandro Andreatta, Tito Boeri, Innocenzo Cipolletta, Paolo Collini, Gregorio De Felice, Maurizio Fugatti, Giuseppe Laterza

coordinated by Eva Giovannini

sessions.title: What to do about Populism
sessions.description:
James Robinson
introduced by Tito Boeri

The specter of populism is haunting the world. But what is it exactly? Where does it come from and what should be done about it? We define populism as an anti-elitist exclusionary political strategy which builds a coalition of discontented citizens to challenge the status-quo. To understand why this coalition is potentially destabilizing to democracy and how it forms we developed a framework to studying the joint evolution of state and society.

sessions.title: Tutta la città ne parla
sessions.description:
hosted by Pietro Del Soldà 
produced by Cristiana Castellotti with Rosa Polacco

This daily public radio show will broadcast live from the city main’s square during the Festival, discussing the day’s main topics with key speakers, authors and other guests.

sessions.title: The elite and the people: useful conflict
sessions.description:
Nadia Urbinati
introduced by Roberto Mania

The conflict between the few and the many can act as oxygen for political and civil liberties. Especially if, as Machiavelli  said, the many hungry for security supervise the few hungry for power within the framework of a “good order”.

sessions.title: Populist politicians and voters in Sweden
sessions.description:
Torsten Persson
introduced by Marco Panara

Many blame the rise of Sweden’s radical right on the country's open immigration policy. But my recent research points to other drivers. Populist politicians and voters come from groups whose risk of job loss went up in the financial crisis, and whose relative income declined as a result of economic reforms. The fuel for the radical right may thus have been too little, not too much, inclusion.

sessions.title: Immigration to Europe and the welfare state: myth and reality
sessions.description:
Alberto Alesina
introduced by Paola Pica

The recent heavy flow of migrants to Europe has generated a cultural reaction against immigrants and a feeling that they are taking excessive advantage of the welfare state in richer countries. The discussion is frequently based not on real data, but rather on stereotypes and incorrect information, often accentuated by anti-immigration and anti-globalisation parties.

sessions.title: Le riforme dimezzate
sessions.description:
Marco Leonardi
Organised by Egea

discussed with Roberto Mania 
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: The european vote: economic and political consequences
sessions.description:
Elisa Ferreira - Cas Mudde - Jean Pisani-Ferry - Nadia Urbinati
introduced by Nando Pagnoncelli
coordinated by Federico Fubini

What new coalitions are possible in the European Parliament after the elections? What are the implications of polarisation between pro-Europeans and sovereignists? Will the former succeed in working together? And will the latter support the status quo or push for reforms, starting from the European Union budget?

sessions.title: Zapping
sessions.description:
hosted by Giancarlo Loquenzi

Live from the Festival of Economics. For more than twenty years the programme has presented current events through the eyes of Italian and international broadcasters. The show will feature a multimedia space combining radio, TV and social media.

sessions.title: Gran Torino
sessions.description:
(USA, 2008)

directed by Clint Eastwood with Clint Eastwood, Bee Vang, Ahney Her

The effect of globalisation on large industrial cities: urban decay, immigration, clash of cultures, nationalist temptations.

sessions.title: Dangerous Liaisons. The State and globalisation from Parliament to the web
sessions.description:
Sabino Cassese
interviewers Annalisa Cuzzocrea and Pietro Del Soldà

Do national states make use of of globalisation, or does the latter constrain them?  In the last thirty years, the relations between national political institutions, the machinery of the state and global markets have changed radically. The analysis and experience of a jurist, minister and constitutional judge involved in modernising our country.

sessions.title: Radio anch'io
sessions.description:
hosted by Giorgio Zanchini 

Live from the Festival of Economics, one of Italy’s longest-running radio shows interacts  with listeners while featuring  investigative and special reports from Italy and around the world.

sessions.title: Tutta la città ne parla
sessions.description:
presented by Pietro Del Soldà 
organised by Cristiana Castellotti with Rosa Polacco

Guests, topics, books and testimony: the Festival appointments recounted live every day for the public in the Piazza and Radio 3 listeners.

sessions.title: Globalisation
sessions.description:
Piero Stanig
introduced by Mauro Caselli 

Several waves of globalisation, understood as the intensification of commercial, demographic and cultural exchanges between very distant areas, have materialized in history. The penultimate one, at the end of the 19th century and in the first decades of the 20th, concluded tragically with a world war and  authoritarian movements grabbing power in many European countries. What is the future of  the  globalisation phase that we are currently crossing?

sessions.title: Measuring poverty around the world di Anthony B. Atkinson
sessions.description:
Andrea Brandolini
organised by Princeton University Press

discussed with Elena Granaglia, Giovanni Vecchi
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: Europe, what now?
sessions.description:
Innocenzo Cipolletta - Ilvo Diamanti - Enrico Letta
coordinated by Erick Jozsef

From elections to governing.  How will Europe change after the vote? More nationalism and “populocracy” or more economic and political integration?

sessions.title: The backlash against globalization: lessons from history
sessions.description:
Kevin O'Rourke
introduced by Marco Bracconi

I will survey three economic history literatures that can speak to contemporary challenges to globalization, including Brexit and the election of Donald Trump: the literature on the anti-globalization backlash of the nineteenth century, focused largely on trade and migration; the literature on the Great Depression, focused largely on capital flows, the gold standard, and protectionism; and the literature on trade and warfare.

sessions.title: Motorways: local requests, global openings
sessions.description:
organised by A22

coordinated by Luigi Olivieri
speakers: Carlo Cambini, Ennio Cascetta, Claudio Cataldi, Barbara Marchetti, Lorenzo Saltari

According to European law, motorway concessions are subject to the same regulations as public contracts. They are awarded through public competition that is also open to the private sector. What opportunities and risks does this system involve for the efficiency of the system and the safeguarding of local requests?

sessions.title: Aliens without frontiers
sessions.description:
organised by Fondazione Edmund Mach

coordinated by Andrea Segrè 
speakers: Piero Genovesi, Annapaola Rizzoli, Nikolaos Stilianakis 

In a globalised world, invasive species move freely across national frontiers, altering the ecological components of agricultural and environmental systems. Alien insects indeed create problems for production sectors such as agriculture and tourism, but also for human health.

sessions.title: Nationalism: at the origins of an idea
sessions.description:
Maurizio Viroli
introduced by Carlo Martinelli

Macron’s nationalism appears very different from Trump’s. To understand the reasons, it is useful to go back to the origin of the concept of modern European political thought, and to the distinction between fatherland, understood as a community of free citizens opposed to tyranny and the nation, understood as a culturally homogeneous community that fights to establish its own identity.

sessions.title: Terrorist attacks and votes for the populist right-wing
sessions.description:
Francesco Giavazzi
Introduced by  Alessandro Russello

We study the recent increase in support for a radical right-wing party in Germany (AfD) relating it to the cultural backlash associated with a number of terrorist attacks, which happened in Europe around the same time, and a very salient incident which occurred in the city of Cologne on New Year’s Eve 2015/2016.  Our results are a first step towards understanding cultural backlash as a channel of transmission of radical right support, which has been traditionally difficult to study and which we can address in the appropriate way using new data and techniques.

sessions.title: A basic universal income?
sessions.description:
Hilary Hoynes
Introduced by Tito Boeri

What are the problems that a genuine ‘citizen’s income’ wishes to address? How does it interact with other welfare programmes? What are the effects in terms of distribution and costs? Answers based on the facts, as in the tradition of Alan Krueger's lectures  at our Festival.

sessions.title: Identity of places: what is the role of culture?
sessions.description:
organised by Trento OECD Centre for Local Development, in collaboration whit tsm - Trentino School of Management

coordinated by Ekaterina Travkina 
speakers: Joana Sousa Monteiro, Michele Trimarchi 

Cities and regions and their societies are the results of complex stratifications of identities, relationships and behaviors. What is the contribution of culture to the identity of places and how can culture and cultural heritage contribute to the development of localities challenged by globalisation?

sessions.title: Multinational companies and local development
sessions.description:
organised by "Lavoce.info"

with Elsa Artadi, Peter Bodin, Mauro Casotto, Licia Mattioli 

introduced by Giorgio Barba Navaretti 
coordinated by Massimo Gaggi

How can cities and regions attract more investment from multinational businesses? And when they succeed, what is the impact on local development? More employment, capital and technology? Or more uncertainty and competition for local businesses?

sessions.title: Ho imparato. In viaggio con i giovani sognando un'Italia mondiale
sessions.description:
Enrico Letta
organised by Il Mulino

discussed  with Sofia Ventura 
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: Immigration, Natives’ Backlash, and Cultural Assimilation: Lessons from US History
sessions.description:
Marco Tabellini
introduced by Nunzia Penelope

The recent rise in immigration has sparked a heated debate on its economic and social consequences. Support for right wing and anti-establishment parties, which tend to rely on a strongly anti-immigrant rhetoric, has grown astonishingly in almost every European country and in the US over the last decade. In this lecture, I focus on the first three decades of the 20th century, when millions of European immigrants moved to the United States, during the Age of Mass Migration. The first part of the lecture studies the political and economy impact of immigration in receiving cities, and explores the causes of natives’ backlash. It shows that political opposition to immigration can arise even when immigrants bring economic prosperity. These findings suggest that diversity might be economically desirable but politically hard to manage. The second part of the lecture investigates the factors that help or hinder the cultural assimilation of immigrants. In particular, it discusses how the inflow of new (ethnic and social) out-groups can influence the social inclusion of previous outsiders, and how the size of immigrant enclaves mediates their ability and their willingness to assimilate.

sessions.title: Voting patterns, Regions left behind and policy responses: the raise of the places that don't matter
sessions.description:
Andrés Rodriguez-Pose
organised by OCSE

introduced by Alexander Lembcke 

Persistent poverty, economic decay and lack of opportunities are causing discontent in declining regions. Many of these so-called "places that don't matter" revolt in a wave of political populism with strong territorial foundations. How can policymakers reverse this trend and provide opportunities to those people living in the places that don't matter?

sessions.title: Authoritarian populism
sessions.description:
Pippa Norris - Nadia Urbinati
coordinated by Mario Garofalo

Pippa Norris via video link discusses with Nadia Urbinati

sessions.title: Tutta la città ne parla
sessions.description:
hosted by Pietro Del Soldà 
produced by Cristiana Castellotti with Rosa Polacco

This daily public radio show will broadcast live from the city main’s square during the Festival, discussing the day’s main topics with key speakers, authors and other guests.

sessions.title: In safety and freedom: the appeal of syrian refugees
sessions.description:
organised by Associazione Comunità Papa Giovanni XXIII - Operazione Colomba

speakers: Alberto Capannini, Abdel Rahim Hsyan, Eli Schlein 

Since 2011, millions of Syrian refugees have fled war in order to avoid fighting, imprisonment or death: they survive in extreme conditions in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey. Reflections on their appeal to the international community for the creation of conditions allowing them security and freedom.

sessions.title: A battle of words. The game of cross-examination
sessions.description:
organised by Comune di Trento - Servizio cultura, turismo e politiche giovanili con il coordinamento di IPRASE, Facoltà di Giurisprudenza dell’Università di Trento e Comuni di Trento e Rovereto

speakers: Cristina Azzolini, Maria Chiara Franzoia, Paolo Sommaggio, Chiara Tamanini and high school pupils

Is it more important to understand local processes or global reality in order to develop an area community? Pupils from regional high schools will address this  subject in the final of the debate championship whose goal is to educate young people to participate in democratic dialogue.

sessions.title: Austerity. Quando funziona e quando no
sessions.description:
Alberto Alesina - Carlo Favero - Francesco Giavazzi
organised by Rizzoli

discussed with Paolo Guerrieri 
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: The errors of the elite at the origin of sovereignism
sessions.description:
Jan Zielonka
introduced by Giuseppe Laterza

The liberal elites that have governed the West in the last thirty years have made many mistakes: underestimating inequality, using technical skill as a substitute for political representation, trusting in the redistribution ability of the free market and misguided migratory policies.

sessions.title: Is secular stagnation in our future? Lessons from the past
sessions.description:
Joel Mokyr
introduced by Andrea Fracasso 

The question of whether industrialized economies can continue to grow has been discussed in the past ten years, as growth rates have slowed down. Some economists have argued that the advanced economies are doomed to secular stagnation and that growth at high rates is over for good. This is examined in view of economic history and the determinants of past economic growth.

sessions.title: (on populism and globalisation) Is another form of globalization possible?
sessions.description:
Donatella Della Porta
introduced by Simone Pieranni

Globalisation has been perceived by many as responsible for increasing social inequality and political dissatisfaction, which were further accentuated during the Great Recession. However, criticism of globalisation takes very different forms, with responses going from xenophobic populism to proposal of a “different form of globalisation”, inclusive and coming from below.

sessions.title: Protectionism and globalisation in italian businesses
sessions.description:
organised by GEI Gruppo Economisti di Impresa

coordinated by Massimo Deandreis 
speakers: Innocenzo Cipolletta, Gregorio De Felice, Alessandra Lanza

The Italian association of business economists presents recent research by its members on the relationship between business and economic globalisation.

sessions.title: Who’s afraid of Libya?
sessions.description:
organised by Centro per la Cooperazione Internazionale di Trento

coordinated by Mario Raffaelli
speaker: Gian Franco Damiano

Since the fall of General Gaddafi’s regime in 2011, Libya has experienced a period of tension and internal conflict. What is the role of Libyan municipalities in the tortuous process of reconstructing a state and a national community, iamong internal divisions and external interference?

sessions.title: Immigration and demographic scenarios
sessions.description:
organised by Fondazione Iniziative e Studi sulla Multietnicità - ISMU

coordinated by Giancarlo Blangiardo 
speakers: Luigi Bonatti, Mario Raffaelli, Laura Zanfrini 

A panel discussion on migration, in light of the different demographic dynamics in the areas of origin and destination of migratory flows. An opportunity to analyse future international mobility scenarios in economic and socio-demographic terms and in relation to welfare.

sessions.title: (on populism and rational voters) How the victims of globalisation react
sessions.description:
Rafael Di Tella
introduced by Eugenio Occorsio

We study preferences for protectionism in response to unemployment resulting from different types of labor market shocks. These include technological change, a demand shift, bad management, and three kinds of international outsourcing. Demand for import protection increases significantly in all cases, except for the “bad management” shock. Effects appear to be heterogeneous across subgroups with different political preferences and education. Trump supporters are more protectionist than Clinton supporters, but preferences seem easy to manipulate: Clinton supporters primed with trade shocks are as protectionist as baseline Trump voters. Highlighting labor abuses in the exporting country increases the demand for trade protection by Clinton supporters but not Trump supporters.

sessions.title: Contrordine compagni. Manuale di resistenza alla tecnofobia per la riscossa del lavoro e dell'Italia
sessions.description:
Marco Bentivogli
organised by Rizzoli

discussed with Giorgio Barba Navaretti, Luigi Zanda
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: How Nations are born (and why nationalism returns)
sessions.description:
Alberto Mario Banti
introduced by Simonetta Fiori

From racial continuity to the proximity of land, there is a thread running through all forms of nationalism, past and the present. It begins with the real and symbolic construction of modern nations such as Italy.

sessions.title: Do populists handle austerity better?
sessions.description:
Wolfgang Munchau - George Papacostantinou
coordinated by Ferdinando Giugliano

To which extent did the economic policies carried out by Syriza in Greece differ from those of previous governments? Was the austerity program under Syriza more socially aware and friendlier towards those most vulnerable? More generally, do populists pursue different policies? A discussion between a key player in the negotiations with the Troika and an acute observer of the European management of the Greek tragedy.

sessions.title: Balance of power: states, societies and the narrow corridor to liberty
sessions.description:
Daron Acemoglu - Antonio Spilimbergo
coordinated by Alessandro Barbera

This talk will argue that the foundations of institutions that protect individual liberty and create an environment conducive to economic growth are not in clever institutional designs or top-down development of state institutions. Rather, they emerge from the involvement of society in politics in a way that balances the power of state institutions and elites. This precarious balance, when it is achieved, unleashes a powerful process of building of state capacity and development of society's capability to institutionalize its involvement in politics. The corridor leading to such institutions is narrow because of the difficulty of creating this balance and staying the course despite myriad conflicts and gridlocks.

Daron Acemoglu via video link discusses with Antonio Spilimbergo

sessions.title: Populism in Turkey
sessions.description:
organised by Centro per la Cooperazione Internazionale - Osservatorio Balcani e Caucaso Transeuropa

introduced by Mario Raffaelli 
speakers: Cengiz Aktar, Esra Çeviker Gürakar, Fazila Mat 

There have been major changes in Turkey in the last seventeen years. An initial reformist phase has been replaced by an authoritarian system, and growth by a profound economic crisis. Only Erdogan’s power has remained unaltered thanks to which economic and political strategies?

sessions.title: Brexit and the UK labour market
sessions.description:
Barbara Petrongolo
introduced by Roberta Carlini

Immigration was a key factor in the result of the Brexit referendum in 2016. However, most of the studies of the labour market find no negative effects of immigration on the salaries and employment levels of “locals”, nor on public finances. So what is the reason for the attitudes towards immigrants and their impact on political choices in the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe?

sessions.title: European institutions and populism
sessions.description:
Carlo Ruzza - Markus Warasin
coordinated by Silvia Sciorilli Borrelli

In recent years populist parties have had considerable success. How do EU institutions and civil society organizations react at European level? What ideas and strategies do they propose to deal with their impact?

sessions.title: Il grande carrello. Chi decide cosa mangiamo
sessions.description:
Fabio Ciconte - Stefano Liberti
organised by Editori Laterza

discussed with Giorgio Santambrogio
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: From isolated individual to citizen of a community
sessions.description:
organised by AIF - Associazione Italiana Formatori

speakers: Antonello Calvaruso, Domenico De Masi, Maurizio Milan

Everyday life is characterised by migratory phenomena disturbing deep-seated historic cultural values. In order to encourage social inclusion, training must create learning environments to reconstruct a sense of belonging to a community, allowing diversity to permeate it.

sessions.title: The rise of populism: causes and consequences
sessions.description:
Cas Mudde
introduced by Simonetta Nardin

Politics in the early 21st is characterized by the rise of populism, in which “the people” are pitted against “the elite,” but what explains the rise of populist parties and what are the consequences of populist politics.

sessions.title: Globalisation and universalism: the new frontiers between the right and the left
sessions.description:
Colin Crouch
introduced by Giorgio Zanchini

In the last few decades economic globalisation  has not been accompanied by universalism of human and welfare rights. The gap has encouraged favoured the establishment of populism and nationalism and has called into question consolidated distinctions, starting from the difference between left and right.

sessions.title: Regional autonomy in Italy
sessions.description:
Mario Bertolissi - Floriana Cerniglia - Fulvio Cortese - Gianfranco Viesti
coordinated by Eugenio Occorsio

Where are we in the process of implementing constitutional norms making it possible to assign “further forms and particular conditions of autonomy” to regions without special status? What role should Parliament have in this phase? What are the criteria on the basis of which to identify further roles attributable to regions? What is the funding mechanism for these roles as regards respect for equalisation principles and budget constraints?

sessions.title: Zapping
sessions.description:
hosted by GIANCARLO LOQUENZI

Live from the Festival of Economics. For more than twenty years the programme has presented current events through the eyes of Italian and international broadcasters. The show will feature a multimedia space combining radio, TV and social media.

sessions.title: Bread and chocolate
sessions.description:
(Italia, 1973)

directed by Franco Brusati with Nino Manfredi, Paolo Turco, Gianfranco Barra

A great Italian comedian takes us back to ta not so distant past when we were the victims of xenophobic nationalism..

organised by Marco Onado and Andrea Landi

sessions.title: European voices. an evening dedicated to Antonio Megalizzi
sessions.description:
Annalisa Camilli - Graham Ellis - Nicola Pifferi - Silvia Sciorilli Borrelli
coordinated by Eric Jozsef
speaker: Andrea Fracasso

Without public support at European level it is difficult to imagine political union. To create it, exchanges between national media are necessary, along with the creation of places for the exchange of transnational information, analysis and discussion. There is a new generation that considers itself European and seeks critical and selected information. Antonio Megalizzi a young Italian reporter tragically killed in the December terrorist attacks in Strasburg, belonged to this generation.

sessions.title: People / populism
sessions.description:
Luigi Guiso
introduced by Emanuele Massetti 

The threat of populism is moving across Western societies, generating fears and concerns proportional to the high degree of consensus it attracts.  Why is this happening now and in this part of the world? Is it an unfortunate historical coincidence or an inevitable step for the resolution of  the crisis these societies are in? What are the underlying causes and what are the possible consequences?

sessions.title: Comparing populist movements
sessions.description:
Thomas Ferguson - Thiemo Fetzer - Robert Gold
chaired by Antonella Stirati
Why is populism surging in the world's most advanced economies? This panel compares how economic, cultural, and political factors have affected major country experiences including Germany, the UK and the US, as well ad Italy.

sessions.title: Globalization and Inequality
sessions.description:
Elhanan Helpman
Introduced by Lorenzo Tondo

Globalization has been blamed in the last thirty years for many economic ills, including the rise of inequality. I will discuss the findings of a large body of work on the impact of globalization on inequality. Research does not confirm many popular views.

sessions.title: La scienza inutile. Tutto quello che non abbiamo voluto imparare
sessions.description:
Francesco Saraceno
organized by Luiss

discussed with Floriana Cerniglia, Fausto Panunzi
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: Populism and civil society
sessions.description:
Antonio Spilimbergo
introduced by Paolo Morando

Populists believe that they are the only legitimate representatives of the people. In this vision, what role do fundamental intermediate bodies (including trade unions, associations etc.) play in a liberal democracy? What lessons can we learn from Europe, where intermediate bodies have long played a key role, and Latin America, where populism has been around for a long time?

sessions.title: Are populist foreign policies doomed to fail?
sessions.description:
Andrew Moravcsik
introduced by Chris Giles

Populist foreign policies pursued recently by President Trump, British Brexiteers, and leaders of other European democracies have produced surprisingly little real policy change. Populist rhetoric generally proves to be incompatible with pursuit of the national interest in a globalized world. On most issues, populist governments choose to break their foreign policy promises in order to stay in office.

sessions.title: Economic training in the third millennium
sessions.description:
organised by Associazione Europea per l’Educazione Economica AEEE Italia

coordinated by Roberto Fini 
speakers: Anna Maria Ajello, Nadia Linciano, Antonio Schizzerotto

Data on social mobility, together with national and international assessment of the economic and financial literacy of Italians, show that there is a need to strengthen school programs  about the global economy.

sessions.title: Italy's brain drain? Trends, politics and policy
sessions.description:
organised by Tortuga

coordinated by Jacopo Bassetto
speakers: Massimo Anelli, Lorenzo Maternini, Silvia Merler 

The recent “brain drain” during and after the crisis would appear to have had negative effects not only in the economic field, but also on politics at local level. What are the future consequences for the national political panorama? What policy is required to transform the phenomenon and reverse the trend?

sessions.title: A global perspective for a fair and locally sourced economy
sessions.description:
organisesd by Fondazione Franco Demarchi

coordinated by Daniel Tarozzi 
speakers: Paolo Cacciari, Pietro Valenti 

In a world where the dichotomy between globalisation and localism is still the subject of debate, the discussion will highlight new prospects for an emerging economy that is fair and sustainable, focusing on the value of local areas.

sessions.title: The imperative of growth: what can be done for regions and cities?
sessions.description:
organised by OECD Trento Centre for Local Development

coordinated by Alessandra Proto 
speakers: Antonio Accetturo, Riccardo Crescenzi 

The limited diffusion of technology and knowledge weighs on productivity growth and innovation in OECD countries. What can policies do to facilitate access to global knowledge and exploit the opportunities offered by an increasingly globalized and digitized world? What policies can governments and regions put in place to reduce territorial gaps?

sessions.title: Merci l’Europe! Risposte aux sept mensonges populistes
sessions.description:
Bernard Spitz
organised by Grasset

discussed with Anais Ginori, Lucrezia Reichlin 
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: Globalization, the rise of right-wing parties, and the fall of social democracy
sessions.description:
Joseph Zweimüller
introduced by Tobias Piller

The political landscape in Europe has changed dramatically over the recent years. In many countries, right-wing parties have strongly increased their vote shares, often at the expense of social democrats. To which extent is this driven by globalization – in particular, by the extent and composition of recent immigrant flows, and by exposure to international trade and shrinking manufacturing sectors? I discuss arguments put forth in the recent literature and present results from own research that sheds light on these and related issues.

sessions.title: Trade wars. How global trade is changing
sessions.description:
organised by "lavoce.info"

with Alessia Amighini, Marta Dassù, Daniel Gros, Alberto Viano 
introduced by Andrea Fracasso 
coordinated by Massimo Gaggi 

For some time, the major powers – particularly the United States and China – have challenged each other with unilateral closure and retaliation measures, accusing each other of unfair competition. What is the impact of these phenomena on businesses, workers and consumers?

sessions.title: The war against debt
sessions.description:
Renato Brunetta - Laura Castelli - Carlo Cottarelli - Massimo Garavaglia - Piercarlo Padoan
coordinated by Lucia Annunziata

Everyone seems to agree that high public debt is a weakness of the Italian economy and must be reduced … but how should this be achieved? A discussion with representatives from the main political forces in our country.

sessions.title: Digital populism. Politics in the internet era
sessions.description:
Mauro Calise - Stefano Zanero
coordinated by Jacopo Iacoboni 

Internet has radically transformed the rules of the political game. The web has generated new parties and movements and social media networks are by now widely identified with public opinion. The building of an online consensus uses tools that are visible and accessible, but also hidden means, available only to a few, that we should be aware of.

sessions.title: How Many “Eurozone” Economies?
sessions.description:
organised by INET

speakers: Matteo Cavallaro, Mustafa Erdem Sakinç, Anna Maria Simonazzi 

This panel analyzes political and economic factors that play unexpectedly, play a major roles in the Eurozone. Little-noticed differences within and between countries will be discussed.

sessions.title: Otium –young people cry out
sessions.description:
organised by the students of secondary institutes in Trento, in collaboration with the Municipality of Trento and the MUSE

Otium is a day of workshops, actions, music and ideas, created by young people for young people. It is a chance to participate, exchange ideas and reflect together on the objectives of sustainable development, discussed with Enrico Giovannini and some young youtubers.

sessions.title: Cooperating to achieve inclusive growth
sessions.description:
organised by Associazione Trentino con i Balcani

coordinated by Maurizio Camin
speakers: Raffaele Crocco, Mario Raffaelli, Antonella Valmorbida 

Starting from an experience in the Balkans,  and in order to offer  a broader vision of the world,  the panel will present four actions that  promote local democracy, decentralised community cooperation, information awareness and sustainable development,  providing  instruments to combat nationalist impulses.

sessions.title: The identity of the Euroregion in the kitchen
sessions.description:
organised by the University of Trento’s Department of Psychology and Neuroscience and Department of Sociology and Social Research
coordinated by Giovanna A. Massari
speakers: Giovanna Degli Avancini, Alessandro Luigini, Massimo Montanari 

Can cooking recipes demonstrate the glocal culture at the beginning of the 20th century? They can when the diet suggests an area and transnational identity. Graphic communication and digital images indeed allow free access to information on the gastronomic culture in the Euroregion.

sessions.title: Making decentralisation work
sessions.description:
Stefano Bonaccini - Fernando Freire De Sousa - Maurizio Fugatti
organised by OCSE

coordinated by Dorothée Allain-Dupré 

Making the most of decentralisation for regional development is crucial in the current context of a "geography of discontent" and growing divides between places that feel left behind by globalisation and those that may benefit from the opportunities offered by megatrends. What makes decentralisation systems wok in a more effective way?

sessions.title: Scusi Prof. Cos'è il populismo?
sessions.description:
Andrea Boitani - Rony Hamaui
organised by Vita e Pensiero

discussed with Alberto Martinelli, Fabio Martini
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: The fall of the aspiration wall
sessions.description:
Ghazala Azmat
introduced by Regina Krieger

How does ones’ politico-economic environment shape aspirations and choices? Decisions are generally made within a specific set of social norms, rules, values and world views. We study how during the German Reunification, convergence with West Germany influenced the educational aspirations and eventual educational investments of students in the East.

sessions.title: Discover, explore and analyse. Public finance accessible to all
sessions.description:
Presentation of the OpenBDAP portal, organised by the State General Accounting Office
introduced and coordinated by Pino Donghi 

speakers: Carlo Cottarelli, Carmine Di Nuzzo, Federico Falcitelli, Daniele Franco, Enrico Giovannini 

The OpenBDAP portal is part of a broad initiative by the State General Accounting Office to develop and update a data ecosystem, along with analysis and dissemination, around its computer systems. Set up as a single point of access to accounting and public finance data, it is available to citizens as well as specialists in need of certified analytical data.

sessions.title: Austerity, the euro and populism
sessions.description:
Lars Feld - Gustavo Piga - Beatrice Weder Di Mauro
coordinated by Rossella Bocciarelli

What are the prospects for the Euro and European fiscla policy co-ordination after the European elections? The popular support for the common currency has been increasing lately in most countries. But doesn't a common currency also require co-ordination in fiscal policies? How much does the spread of nationalism challenge the supranational authority?

sessions.title: Competition award ceremony
sessions.description: The EconoMia competition  rewards 20 high school students who offered the best written analysis of this year's theme. The winners will attend all events of the Festival,  thus learning more about a major issue in contemporary economics.

sessions.title: New forms of representation: a comparison of Italian cities
sessions.description:
organised by Associazione Nazionale dei Direttori Generali degli Enti Locali - ANDIGEL

coordinated by Carlo Mochi Sismondi 
speakers: Michele Bertola, Giacomo Capuzzimati, Chiara Morandini

How do local public administrations address globalisation and new forms of representation of interest groups? Director generals from several Italian cities will investigate the impact of the transformation underway in the organisation of local public administrations and its innovative significance.

sessions.title: Democracy at risk
sessions.description:
Daniel Ziblatt - Sergio Fabbrini
introduced by Eva Giovannini

Liberal and democratic systems are growingly experiencing an authoritarian regression, even when they follow legal electoral and institutional procedures. This is what is happening in Trump’s America and in many other countries, from Turkey to Hungary. The way to avoid an authoritarian drift is for both citizens and political leaders to be alert to the danger in time and to act accordingly.
Daniel Ziblatt via video link, in a dialogue with Sergio Fabbrini

sessions.title: Il sentiero stretto e oltre. Conversazione con Dino Pesole
sessions.description:
Pier Carlo Padoan
organised by Il Mulino

discussed with Massimo Bordignon, Elsa Fornero
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: Citizens’s income and european rules
sessions.description:
Tommaso Monacelli - Pasquale Tridico
coordinated by Dario Laruffa 

Can the citizen’s income scheme lead to greater budgetary flexibility while respecting European rules? What are its probable effects on the workforce, unemployment and national income?

sessions.title: Understanding religions as competing platforms: what has happened to religion in the world since the second world war?
sessions.description:
Paul Seabright
introduced by Pietro Veronese

Over the last 65 years there has been a large rise in the share of Muslims in the world population and a decline in the share of Christians, but the big story is not one about the former growing at the expense of the latter, since the movement in their relative shares reflects almost entirely the different demographics of the populations in which the two religions were more strongly implanted at the beginning of the postwar era. Instead, the story is about local and folk religions all over the world being replaced by organisations representing one of the two major global religious identities. This lecture will look at how religions compete with each other in the global and local marketplaces.

sessions.title: Basic income, nationalism and globalization
sessions.description:
Philippe Van Parijs
introduced by Dino Pesole

An unconditional basic income differs from social assistance, including Italy’s reddito di cittadinanza, in three aspects: it is strictly individual, it is not means-tested and it is not work-tested. Does its political feasibility require some form of nationalism? Does globalization undermine its economic sustainability?

sessions.title: Globalisation and local economies
sessions.description:
organised by Società Italiana degli Economisti

coordinated by Roberta Rabellotti 
speakers: Anna Giunta, Lucia Tajoli, Alessandra Venturini 

What is the impact of the global market on local markets? How can global value chains change local production models? What is the role of migration flows on local development systems?

sessions.title: Caudillismo yesterday and today in South America and beyond
sessions.description:
Enrique Krauze
introduced by Francesco D'Ayala

In South America, the Right and the Left are similar in their glorification the Pueblo, like Perón did in the past and Chavez and Maduro today. A central role is played by the caudillo, the charismatic leader who with masterly manipulation of words constructs his own “truth”, uses public resources at his discretion, keeps his supporters continuously mobilised against “external” enemies, despises legality and undermines the roots of liberal institutions.

sessions.title: Geografia economica dell’Europa sovranista
sessions.description:
Gianmarco Ottaviano
organised by Editori Laterza

discussed with Colin Crouch, Marta Dassù
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: Conflict, migration and populism
sessions.description:
Filippo Grandi
Interviewers: Annalisa Camilli e Francesca Mannocchi 

The combination of extensive and prolonged conflict, consequential forced migration on a large scale, new challenges to asylum rights, the gap between financial resources and humanitarian needs, and growing xenophobia has generated an explosive mixture. What the UNHCR can do, and what national and local governments can do, starting from the cities. The opinion of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

sessions.title: The insult
sessions.description:
directed by ZIAD DOUEIRI with ADEL KARAM, RITA HAYEK, KAMEL EL BASHA

How heightened nationalism can transform a commonplace argument into a settling of scores between different nations, cultures and religions.

organised by Marco Onado and Andrea Landi

sessions.title: Liberal democracy or dictatorship of the majority?
sessions.description:
John Bercow
interviewers: Enrico Franceschini, Tim Hames 

Squeezed between the rise of autocracies and the wave of populism, liberal democracy seems to be in a crisis. Will the "worst kind of government, except for all the others", as Churchill called it, be able to survive? We will ask John Bercow, Speaker of the House of Commons, known as "the mother of all parliaments". In conversation with Tim Hames, former Assistant Editor of The Times, and Enrico Franceschini, columnist of La Repubblica from London.

sessions.title: Sovereignty
sessions.description:
Gianmarco Ottaviano
introduced by Louisa Parks

A sovereign state is independent if its territory is inviolable. Its sovereignty is however conditioned by international agreements and organisations. Sovereignism rejects this conditioning, refusing the multilateral and supranational logic: what are the economic and political consequences?

sessions.title: The geography of discontent
sessions.description:
Riccardo Fraccaro - Fernando Freire De Sousa - Peter Kurz - Jim O'Neill
organised by OCSE

introduced by Joaquim Oliveira Martins

Regional economic divergence has become a threat to economic progress, social cohesion and political stability in Europe. The geography of discontent highlights the inability of current market processes and policies in spreading prosperity and opportunity. What are the policies put in place by selected OECD countries to reverse this trend?

sessions.title: The third pillar. how markets and the state leave the community behind
sessions.description:
Raghuram G. Rajan
organised by Egea

discussed with Luigi Guiso, Pier Carlo Padoan
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: Populism and lay misunderstanding of economics
sessions.description:
David Leiser
introduced by Paolo Mantovan

There are profound reasons why the public misunderstands economics in predictable ways, rooted in the mismatch between our human cognitive endowment and economic analysis. This impacts public policy everywhere, but especially when populists control the economy, as their self-presentation as one with “the people” compels them to embrace simplistic views that resonate with those of the lay public.

sessions.title: The failure of the left
sessions.description:
Federico Rampini
introduced by Massimo Mazzalai

Why has the working class all over the West moved politically to the right? The opening up of markets, a multi-ethnic society, technological revolutions, foreign and budgetary constraints: the reasons behind the divorce of the left from its people, based on the experiences of a correspondent in Europe, China and the USA.

sessions.title: Roadmap to 2030
sessions.description:
speakers: Enrico Giovannini, Michele Lanzinger, Mario Tonina

The Sustainable Development Goals of the UN’s 2030 Agenda represent guidelines for constructing the future of mankind on this planet. A dialogue focusing on the strategies it is planned to put into effect in Italy and Trentino to achieve the ambitious goals for sustainability.

sessions.title: Intermediate bodies: a response to the winds of crisis?
sessions.description:
organised by Gruppo Giovani Imprenditori del Terziario di Confcommercio Trentino

coordinated by Alberto Faustini 
speakers: Giovanni Bort, Nadio Delai, Fausto Manzana 

In times of economic crisis intermediate bodies must reinforce their value as meeting points for the management of social interaction. The real challenge that is underway is to provide concrete and qualified support to new generations of entrepreneurs, encouraging overall recovery, growth and development.

sessions.title: (On the effects of under-employment on the rise of populism) So where have all the good jobs gone?
sessions.description:
David G. Blanchflower
introduced by Luca De Biase

The unemployment figures hide dramatic statistics regarding underemployment, underpaid work and jobs of a few hours. Young people and the less educated are increasingly underemployed, while immigrants are erroneously blamed for this worsening in the quality of work. What can be done to change this situation?

sessions.title: WELFARE, POPULISM and the crisis of the middle class
sessions.description:
organised by CEST - Centro per l’Eccellenza e gli Studi Transdisciplinari

coordinated by Daniela Arlia 
speakers: Lorenza Antonucci, Italo Colantone, Luigi Guiso

The rise and fall of the middle classes redesigns two crucial aspects of contemporary society: voting and consumer preferences. How can states respond to expectations, in terms of welfare, from this part of the population and deal with the rise of new populism?

sessions.title: Where Europe ends
sessions.description:
organised by "lavoce.info"

with Sergio Fabbrini, Maurizio Landini, Alberto Martinelli, Simona Piattoni, Lucrezia Reichlin 

introduced by Massimo Bordignon 
coordinated by Massimo Gaggi 

The European Union is a hircocervus: much more than a simple free trade agreement between sovereign states but much less than a federation. This strange creature creates tensions between citizens and Europe, and economic disparities between member states. What institutional innovations are necessary and possible to make this creature more effective?

sessions.title: More opportunities than constraints
sessions.description:
Ignazio Visco
with Ferruccio De Bortoli, Valentina Romei

Europe is in a stalemate: lots of praiseworthy intentions and statements, but few concrete actions. The often narrow-minded defence of national interests, including when managing  economic and financial policies, must not hinder the establishment of a more effective common governance, which is the only way to effectively deal with the problems raised by globalisation, demographic processes and unprecedented technological changes.

sessions.title: Io Khaled vendo uomini e sono innocente. La tirannia dell'intimità
sessions.description:
Francesca Mannocchi
organised by Einaudi

discussed with Stefano Allievi 
coordinated by Tonia Mastrobuoni

sessions.title: The destiny of experts in the 21st century
sessions.description:
Robert Johnson - Annalisa Rosselli - Michael Spence
organised by INET

How the perception of skills has changed in the plast few years. The role played by populism growth, and what experts can do to regain citizens’ confidence.

sessions.title: Consumers and the single european market
sessions.description:
organised by Altroconsumo

coordinated by Marino Melissano
speakers: Stefano Da Empoli, Samantha Rose, Alice Rovati 

The single European market is continuously evolving and requires constant adaptation to new emerging needs, guaranteeing uniform and greater safeguards for all European consumers, who can purchase products and services by comparing what is on offer from an ever greater number of operators.

sessions.title: Tertium (non) datur: the cooperative alternative
sessions.description:
organised by EURICSE

coordinated by Simone Casalini 
speakers: Carlo Borzaga, Giancarlo Provasi, Marianella Sclavi 

If Keynesianism established the rule of the state over the market and neoliberalism the subjugation of the state to market principles, is it really true that there is no alternative? Can the cooperative system respond to the major political, social and economic transformations underway?

sessions.title: State, market and local communities
sessions.description:
Raghuram G. Rajan
introduced by Tito Boeri

The interaction between state, market and local communities is fundamental in the functioning of a democracy. What happens when globalisation leads to the prevalence of the state and market over local communities? What can be done to restore an equilibrium in which the third pillar has a greater role?

sessions.title: Sustainable austerity
sessions.description:
Olivier Blanchard - Giovanni Tria
coodinated by Ferdinando Giugliano

How virtuous must a country with a high level of debt like Italy be in terms of fiscal policy? What represents a dangerous level of public debt? What can a government do to fight economic stagnation?

sessions.title: Ten Years After: From Financial Crisis to Yellow Vests
sessions.description:
John Ralston Saul
Since 2008 we have been paying for the refusal of Western elites to deal with their own failures. Now we witness a defensive explosion in the population who have been literally forced by the mainstream elites to turn to irresponsible leaders. All sides have forgotten that the source of legitimacy in any democracy is the citizenry. Maintenance of that legitimacy depends critically on citizen engagement in the public good - not ripping it down, but building it in an inclusive and empathetic way.

sessions.title: Democracy and growth: a comparison of Italy and China
sessions.description:
Innocenzo Cipolletta - Paolo Collini - Francesco Grillo
We are faced with two paradoxes: innovation that has not produced real growth in industrialised counties, and democracy that appears to suffer precisely after the fall of communism and the triumph of the market economy. Technological innovation has presumably led to a substantial change in the economic and social mechanisms that generate growth and democracy. The behaviour of two very different countries such as China and Italy can act as a starting point for a useful reflection.

sessions.title: The global action of a non-profit-making organisation
sessions.description:
organised by Rotary Club Trento

coordinated by Luca Pianesi
speakers: Paolo Bordon, Massimo Fedrizzi, Maria Grazia Zuccali

The End Polio Now project directed at the eradication of polio is a humanitarian initiative operating at global level, with local monitoring groups: an example how to intervene to solve global problems, particularly in the field of healthcare.

sessions.title: The populist challenge to democracy in Germany and Europe: threat or corrective?
sessions.description:
Wolfgag Merkel
introduced by Michael Braun

All over Europe, the populist right has taken hold through some shared ideas, such as the rejection of immigrants and of free circulation of goods and assets, and the opposition to supranational institutions. The consequence of their success though may be very different in each country, depending on the steadiness of their liberal and democratic systems. The question arises whether a threat to democracy can be transformed in a democratic corrective.

sessions.title: Green Growth in Dual Economies: Or Why the Road to Hothouse Earth is Paved with Good Intentions
sessions.description:
Servaas Storm
This lecture assesses what has so far been accomplished in terms of decarbonisation and energy efficiency improvements and compares this to what will be needed to prevent further warming of the earth about 2 degrees C. The structural transformation required to reduce carbon emissions in line with the IPCC target is profound, and, as will be argued, cannot be left to markets, private initiative and/or pecuniary nudges. A green industrial policy might accomplish this, but it will have to overcome powerful tendencies towards dual economies in the world’s most advanced economies.

organizers.name: Pietro Del Soldà
organizers.bio: Presenter of the programme “Tutta la città ne parla”, Rai Radio3

organizers.name: Rosa Polacco
